screening_results.reason: Although the study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants and addresses social cognitive processes (ToM, face/voice perception, biological motion, language), the group-level voxelwise analyses reported were restricted to a bilateral STS mask rather than presented as unmasked whole-brain statistical maps. The Methods state that second-level analyses were limited to the STS mask and results/figures focus on STS-restricted activations. Therefore the paper does not provide an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map for the healthy adult group, violating the review’s whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (female HCs, ages 19–36) and uses an fMRI social task, it does not report an unmasked, whole‑brain, group‑level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. Reported whole‑brain results are primarily between‑group contrasts (e.g., BPD>HC for social vs non‑social cues) and an ROI (amygdala) analysis for feedback; no standalone HC whole‑brain task-evoked map or within‑group HC contrast is presented. Because the review requires at least one group‑level, univariate whole‑brain task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group, this paper fails that inclusion criterion and should be excluded.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI (Cyberball) in adults and reports whole-brain group-level activation maps (EX>IN, SUP>EX), the sample includes a mixed group of 37 healthy participants and 9 participants meeting criteria for social anxiety disorder. The paper reports group-level whole-brain results for the entire sample and regression analyses across the whole sample, but does not present univariate whole-brain task effects reported separately for the healthy/control subgroup. Per the review’s eligibility rule that studies including clinical groups must report healthy-group results separately, this study does not satisfy that requirement and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study using a social-interaction task (Cyberball ball-toss) that manipulates frequency of social interaction. Participants were healthy adults (initial N=38, final analyzed N=31; mean age ~21, right-handed, no neurological/medical disorders), within the 17–65 age range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (ball-toss [high-frequency – normal-frequency] > button-press [high-frequency – normal-frequency]) with voxelwise threshold and cluster-level FWE correction, and provides peak coordinates (e.g., right ventral striatum [22,0,-8], precuneus [6,-44,42]). Analyses are univariate task activations generalizable to healthy adults, not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review.

This paper reports task-based fMRI on a social-cognition construct (understanding others’ regret — perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy adult volunteers (two studies, each N=24; ages in reported ranges ~20–31), meeting the 17–65 age criterion. The analysis is whole-brain, group-level, univariate voxelwise (SPM5 random-effects, parametric and conjunction analyses of IP vs IF and OP vs OF), with reported statistical maps and activation foci/coordinates and cluster reports. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and healthy-group task activation maps are clearly described and generalizable. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using the Taylor Aggression Paradigm, a social interaction task assessing retaliatory aggression (social/emotional processing). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=15 males; mean age 22.3), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate random-effects analyses (GLM) and presents voxelwise statistical maps and Talairach coordinates for multiple task contrasts (decision/outcome phases) and parametric modulation results; results are generalizable to the healthy group (not restricted to an arbitrary subgroup). It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a between-group-only paper. Although sample size is small and limited to males (noted in limitations), all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be included.

This is a task-based fMRI hyperscanning study in 44 healthy adult participants (mean age 22.4), investigating interpersonal social exchange (cooperation/competition) — clearly within social processing (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM analyses (FEAT/FLAME) with non-parametric permutation correction and provides cluster coordinates and t-maps for multiple contrasts (goal, interaction, role, interactions). Results are voxelwise and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants in age range, empirical original fMRI data). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication (speech act comprehension: Naming vs Requesting) in healthy adult participants (n=18 analyzed, ages 18–41). The task directly targets social-related processing (perception/understanding of others and communicative actions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses and task contrasts (e.g., Request > Naming) with FDR correction, and results are described in the text and figures/tables; thus whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps for the healthy sample are available. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants are within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study does not meet key inclusion criteria. Sample: participants are adolescents (mean age 14.24 years, range around 14), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Task/domain: the fMRI paradigm is a Monetary Incentive Delay task assessing monetary reward processing (non-social); although maternal affiliation was measured behaviorally, the neuroimaging task does not probe social-related processing (affiliation/attachment, social communication, or perception of others). While group-level task activations are reported, they pertain to an adolescent sample, so do not provide whole-brain evidence generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it fails the age and topical (social-related fMRI in adults) inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (attribution of emotions to human and non-human faces), addressing perception/understanding of others. Sample comprises healthy adults (n=18; ages 21–46) with results reported separately for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Emotion>Expression conjunction across targets; Face>Scramble) with cluster-level FWE correction and whole-brain maps/coordinates. Analyses are not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or non-empirical methods. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked activation in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social touch (self- vs other-touch), a social-related task (perception/understanding of self and others). It includes a clearly reported healthy adult control group (NC; n=30, mean age ~23.7 within 17–65) with separate results. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps for the control group (other-touch and self-touch vs baseline; FWE-corrected whole-brain results and figures/tables described). Results for controls are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes empirical fMRI data in healthy adults). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This fMRI study uses a social judgment task (social acceptance/rejection), i.e. a social-related paradigm. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=20; mean age ~28) reported separately from anorexia patients. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task activation maps and within-group contrasts for controls (acceptance>control; rejection>control) with cluster-based correction (pFWE) and provides coordinates/figures/tables. Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses. Participants are adults within the 17–65 range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI with healthy adult participants and probes social-affective processing (movie-evoked empathic fear), it does not report group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy/control group. The analyses focus on network-level dynamic cohesion (NCI), ROI/network comparisons, connectivity/time-series statistics, and classification; activation results are derived from predefined meta-analytic network nodes rather than whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts. This violates the review’s required ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion and matches the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only connectivity/network/ROI results without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map.

This is an fMRI study of social cooperation (one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma), a social-processing task relevant to perception/understanding of others. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (final n=18; mean age 21.0), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., CC > other outcomes; Gain > Loss; interaction maps) with coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction; whole-brain results are described in text, tables, and figures in addition to ROI analyses. It is empirical, task-based fMRI in healthy adults and does not violate exclusion criteria. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses task fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=36) and examines vocal emotional (social) processing, it does not report any group-level, voxelwise univariate task-evoked whole-brain activation maps. Analyses are ROI-based (Power-264) functional connectivity and graph-theoretical network metrics rather than whole-brain GLM/activation contrasts. This fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one whole-brain, task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=12, ages 20–32) that uses a social-related task (learning facts about people versus buildings and hammers). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise, whole-brain univariate contrasts and conjunction analyses (e.g., person > building and person > hammer), with cluster-corrected statistical maps and region coordinates, generalizable to a healthy adult sample. Although functional connectivity analyses are also reported, these are supplemental and not the sole focus; the primary task-evoked whole-brain results for the healthy group are clearly presented. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain group-level univariate maps) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (imitation/understanding others), conducted in healthy adult participants (n=37; ages 18–25). Reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (parametric modulation and one-sample t-tests) with cluster-corrected thresholds and peak coordinates/figures, not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Whole-brain PPI is also reported but does not replace the univariate task maps. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=25, mean age 25.1, range within 17–65). The task is social: participants learn about other agents’ preferences relative to the self (social cognition; perception/understanding of others/affiliation). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked results (conjunctions, contrasts, cluster-corrected activations with MNI coordinates) and parametric GLM analyses; whole-brain findings for multiple contrasts are clearly described in text/tables/figures. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

While this study uses fMRI during a social-related task (biological motion perception) and includes a healthy adult control group, the reported imaging analyses are primarily ROI-based (STSp and MT) and per-subject localizers. The paper does not provide a clear group-level, whole-brain, univariate task activation map for the healthy/control group (no unmasked, voxelwise healthy-group contrast or whole-brain statistical map is reported in tables/figures for controls). Some whole-brain searches are described (e.g., searching for voxels in patients), but there is no clearly reported whole-brain healthy-group task effect generalizable to the healthy adult population. Because the review requires a group-level whole-brain univariate healthy-control task map, this study does not meet the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (social interaction recognition from point-light displays). The sample includes a healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (SI > NM) for the adult group with voxelwise results, cluster- and peak-level statistics (including FWE-corrected findings) described in the text/tables. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately from child/adolescent groups. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses fMRI during a social-related task (HCP Animated Triangles social cognition paradigm; social vs non-social conditions). (2) Includes a healthy adult group (25 healthy controls, ages matched to patients) and reports their results separately. (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts for the healthy/control group (e.g., visual motion and social>non-social contrasts with MNI coordinates, t-values, and FWE-corrected thresholds). Not excluded: results are not ROI-only or connectivity-only (although DCM is used additionally), and healthy-group whole-brain activation maps are clearly reported. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-interaction perception in healthy adults (ages 18–34). It uses task-based fMRI with univariate, group-level whole-brain analyses (e.g., interaction > independent actions contrast; results reported with FDR correction and surface-based random-effects group analysis). Sample size and participant details for healthy adults are clearly reported. The paper provides whole-brain statistical maps/cluster results and meets the meta-analysis’ requirements for task-evoked, whole-brain healthy-group activation. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (mentalising/theory-of-mind) in healthy adults. Samples include healthy adult participants within the 17–65 range (Experiment 2: N=17, mean age 22; Experiment 1: N=39, mean age 35.5). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses (second-level ANOVAs) and contrasts (e.g., mentalising > factual; parametric modulation) with whole-brain correction and tabulated/visualized results. The reported effects are univariate task-evoked maps for the healthy group and not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Both participant samples are adolescents (task administered at age ~16), not adults. Inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65). Although the study uses task fMRI of social/introspective processing and reports whole-brain, group-level results, it does not include any healthy adult participants or adult subgroup analyses. Therefore it fails the age/sample inclusion criterion.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social perception (perception of others’ head turns — a ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ social construct) in healthy adults (initial N=21, ages 22–38; final analyses on healthy adult participants). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain analyses (nonparametric SnPM and whole gray-matter–masked analyses) with voxelwise results and coordinates (FWE-corrected effects in STS, early visual cortex, MT+, and whole-brain results are described and tabulated/illustrated). Results for the healthy/control group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, includes whole-brain task activation maps). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (social sharing/affiliation) in healthy adults (female participants aged 20–33). The authors performed standard second-level random-effects GLM analyses and report group-level, univariate task contrasts (e.g., shared_emo > unshared_emo) with whole-brain results (whole-brain cluster-level correction reported for exploratory analyses and SPM random-effects model used). Although ROI analyses are presented for VS/OFC, whole-brain task-evoked activations (and cluster-corrected results) are reported and described, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample is within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (guilt vs neutral memories/hypothetical scenarios), addressing social cognition and perception/understanding of others. Participants were healthy adults (mean age 25.7; n=20 proceeded to scanning), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., guilt memories vs neutral memories; guilt memories vs guilt hypotheticals) using whole-brain thresholding (p<0.001, cluster extent) and reports region coordinates and cluster results; thus whole-brain evidence is present and clearly attributable to the healthy group. Analyses also included SVCs but are not limited to ROI-only approaches. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical, task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=12, mean age 26) examining perception/understanding of others’ actions/effort (social cognition: perception and understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (SPM GLM contrasts and polynomial parametric modulation maps) with voxelwise thresholds and SUIT cerebellar analyses; results are described in text, figures, and tables. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, healthy adult group results are reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI task study of narrative comprehension that explicitly probes social cognition (mentalizing/Theory-of-Mind) during listening to literary stories. Sample: healthy adult participants (N=18, ages 18–27) satisfying the age/sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (Mentalizing > Action and Action > Mentalizing) with corrected statistical thresholds and reports activation clusters (e.g., aMPFC, TPJ, STG, PCC) in text/figures. The study therefore provides healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked maps and is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or clinical-only results. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

The study uses task-based fMRI of a social-related process (approachability/social judgment). It includes a healthy adult control group reported separately (controls recruited and compared to clinical groups). Whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses were conducted (social > gender and condition contrasts) with group- and within-group results and voxelwise inference; within-group analyses and control-group results are described (supplementary tables/figures referenced) and whole-brain cluster- and voxel-level statistics are reported. The paper is empirical, not ROI- or connectivity-only, and reports control-group task activation maps/contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Study uses task-based fMRI with a social interaction paradigm (ultimatum game) in healthy adult participants (7–10 male subjects aged 23–28). It reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise results from an offline whole-brain classification analysis: discriminating volumes/brain areas (e.g., LPFC, AI, OFC, VS, vmPFC, pSTS, cerebellum) were extracted from transformed SVM weight vectors and statistical significance per voxel was estimated via permutation testing (p<0.05 uncorrected). These results constitute group-level whole-brain voxelwise findings reported in the text/tables and thus meet the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked evidence. The task is clearly social and participants are healthy adults within the eligible age range. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range participants) are violated.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (empathy toward humans and animals), meeting the review’s construct of Perception/Understanding of Others. Participants are healthy adults (n=60; ages 18–60) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (human negative>neutral; animal negative>neutral) analyzed with SPM; results are reported as voxelwise maps and coordinates with FWE-corrected thresholds and within-group one-sample t tests. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and within-group healthy adult task effects are clearly described and generalizable. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction processing in healthy adults (N=21, ages 18–35). The task involves viewing dynamic social interaction videos (arguing, celebrating, laughing). The paper reports group-level GLM analyses for localizer tasks (e.g., interaction>scrambled, bodies>objects, faces>objects, mentalizing>pain) used to define ROIs, and performed whole-brain searchlight analyses—providing voxelwise, group-level task-evoked maps. Participants are within the required age range and results for the healthy group are reported. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state, not clinical-only). Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy late-adolescent adults (ages 18.1–22.8) performing an action-observation task involving risk-taking vs. safe actions—a social-cognitive paradigm tapping perception/understanding of others and social/emotional processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise SPM analyses (risk-taking vs. safe contrasts) with coordinates, thresholds, and conjunction/mediation analyses; results are presented as whole-brain statistical maps and peak coordinates. Participants fall within the 17–65 adult range and are a healthy control sample. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses, nor is it non-empirical. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although this fMRI study includes healthy adult controls and uses a social cognition task (irony comprehension), the paper does not report a univariate, whole-brain, group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. Results are presented as combined effects across participants and as between-group contrasts (controls > patients) and correlations; the authors note the control-group results were previously published. The exclusion criterion disallows studies that only provide between-group contrasts without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect. Therefore it fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social interaction (joint action: leading, following, mutual) using healthy adult dancers (N=18, mean age 40.4). The study reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses and contrasts (FDR-corrected maps, Talairach coordinates, cluster thresholds) for partnered vs. non-partnered conditions, role-specific contrasts, and improvisation effects. It is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and results for the healthy adult sample are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a naturalistic, socially engaging movie (Toy Story) as a task stimulus and reports group-level, whole-brain nodewise statistical maps for the healthy Adult group (within-group inter-subject correlation maps and peak coordinates). The Adult participants are healthy and reported separately (final N=21 adults), and results are presented as whole-brain statistical maps (with cluster correction and peak MNI coordinates), not ROI-only or resting-state/seed-based connectivity only. The paradigm targets social-cognitive processing and the paper provides univariate, group-level surface/voxelwise tests generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

The study is an fMRI experiment in healthy adults (N=18; mean age 26) investigating perception and categorization of different laughter types—an explicitly social communication task (affiliation/social signaling, perception of others). It reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., CSL>TIC, CAT>COU) with voxelwise thresholds, cluster-level FWE correction, and ROI/conjunction analyses. Results are clearly described as coming from the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is a task-based fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (n=20; age range 24–64). The authors report group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (ToM > R, ToM > Baseline, R > Baseline) with statistical thresholds, cluster correction, and coordinate reporting; figures/tables of activations are described. Results are explicitly from the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study used fMRI during a social (patient–physician) interaction with healthy adult participants (N=18, ages 25–37), the neuroimaging results reported are restricted to a priori ROI-based analyses (5 mm spheres) with FWE correction performed within those ROIs. The paper does not present or describe an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task-evoked statistical map (voxelwise whole-brain contrast generalizable to healthy adults). Because the review requires at least one whole-brain univariate task activation map from the healthy group, this study does not meet the ‘‘whole-brain evidence’’ inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI task study probing social/affiliative processing (attachment) using passive viewing of own vs. unfamiliar child and dog images—directly relevant to the review. Sample comprises healthy adult participants (women aged 22–45) with clinical exclusions; results are reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise within-group contrasts (e.g., own child vs. fixation, own dog vs. fixation, own child vs. own dog) with MNI coordinates and activation maps. Although the authors used an ROI/SVC approach for inferential statistics, they performed a whole-brain voxelwise GLM and present voxel-level contrast results (figures and coordinates) for the healthy group rather than ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Age range and reporting meet inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore include.

This is an fMRI study of self- and other-reflection (social cognition: perception/understanding of self and others). A healthy adult control group (n=21) is included and HC results are reported separately: main task effects for HCs (contrasts self>semantic and other>semantic) are described and whole-brain group-level activations are reported (voxelwise FWE-corrected maps, cluster tables/figures). The task is a task-evoked, univariate whole-brain analysis for the healthy group, meeting the review’s social-related and whole-brain evidence criteria. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not non-empirical, and healthy adults are reported separately). Therefore the study should be included.

This paper reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (thinking about 16 dyadic social interactions) and includes a separately reported healthy adult control group (n=17; matched young adults). The manuscript presents conventional univariate, whole-brain GLM within-group contrasts (social interactions > fixation) for the control group, described in the Results and illustrated with SPM maps (uncorrected p=0.001, extent threshold 5 voxels), satisfying the requirement for a group-level, voxelwise task-evoked map generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, adult participants fall in the appropriate age range, and results for the healthy/control group are reported separately. It does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (empathy for others’ pain — perception/understanding of others). It includes a healthy young adult subgroup (ages 20–30, within 17–65) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation maps/contrasts (pain>no pain; pain>baseline) with tables/figures and NeuroVault links. Although an older group (65–75) is also included, the paper provides whole-brain results that include and compare the young healthy subgroup; data and statistical maps for the task effect are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI- or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of perception of others’ hand actions (weight discrimination), which fits the review construct 'Perception and Understanding of Others.' Healthy adult participants are included and analyzed separately (Experiments 1–4; n=79 healthy participants). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task activation contrasts (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS; weight discrimination GLMs) analyzed in SPM with whole-brain normalization and thresholded statistical maps (reported in main text and figures), satisfying the whole-brain univariate map requirement. Although a clinical group (SCA6) is also included, healthy-group results are reported independently. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and not limited to connectivity/resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

While the study uses an fMRI social task and includes a healthy adult control group (n=30), the imaging analyses are ICA-based (spatially constrained GIG-ICA) with component spatial maps and component-level temporal β-weights. The paper reports mentalizing-related effects as differences in component β-weights and correlations with behavioral scores, not as univariate, voxelwise group-level task activation maps (e.g., TD show>no-show whole-brain contrast) or tables of whole-brain coordinates for healthy participants. Thus it does not provide the required whole-brain, univariate task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group, so it fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception of dynamic vs. static emotional facial expressions) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=13, mean age 24.3, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses for the control group (simple main effect of dynamic > static) with corrected thresholds and describes activation foci (MTG, FG, AMY, MPFC, IFG), satisfying the requirement for a whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for healthy adults. Although a clinical ASD group is also included, results for the healthy/control group are reported separately. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and includes appropriate task-evoked whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adult populations. No exclusion criteria are violated.

While this dual‑fMRI hyperscanning study tests social interaction in healthy adults (N=38, mean age 22.4) and uses task fMRI during cooperative/competitive interactions, it does not report a group‑level univariate whole‑brain (voxelwise) task activation map or standard GLM within‑group contrasts. The primary reported results are group ICA spatial components and inter‑subject correlation (ISC) connectivity/alignment metrics derived from those components. According to the review’s inclusion criteria, studies must provide at least one group-level, univariate whole‑brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy group. Because the paper presents ICA/ISC multivariate/connectivity analyses without an accompanying whole‑brain univariate task activation map, it fails the ‘whole‑brain evidence’ inclusion criterion and should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults: participants (N=14, mean age 29.4) viewed point-light displays depicting social interactions vs non-social motion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects univariate analyses (SI > NSI contrast) with FDR-corrected threshold (p<0.05) and lists significant clusters/coordinates across the brain (pSTS, TPJ, MPFC, IFG, premotor, intraparietal sulcus, etc.). All inclusion criteria are met: task is social-related, sample is healthy adults within 17–65, and whole-brain task-evoked group results are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only; not connectivity- or resting-state-only; not between-group-only). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

The study reports task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample (N=23, ages 19–32). The task involves reading a literary narrative that elicits mentalizing/theory-of-mind and perception/understanding of others (suspense linked to inference about characters), which falls under social-related processing. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (parametric suspense regressor and reading>rating contrast) with cluster-level FWE correction and tables of peak coordinates; results are clearly reported for the healthy participant group. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social interaction (real-time mutual eye contact) in healthy adult participants (mean age ~21.8, N≥30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM contrasts (LIVE > REPLAY) with random-effects analysis and cluster-level FWE correction, and provides detailed cluster results/coordinates and figures. Although additional connectivity and interbrain analyses are reported, the required whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy adult sample are clearly presented. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this fMRI study uses a social-interaction task and includes a healthy adult control group (n=24, mean age ~29), it does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy/control group. The authors explicitly state they focused on an ROI analysis of the arMPFC and that whole-brain or functional connectivity analyses could not be conducted due to signal loss. Thus the paper reports only ROI and between-group results and fails to provide the required unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect, violating the meta-analysis’ whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=20, mean age 20.65) that examines event simulation including social situations (41/96 stimuli depicted social interactions) and contrasts (Exp–Imp, Ftr–Exp, Imp–Con). It reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts with cluster correction (p<0.001 height, p<0.05 cluster) and discusses social-cognition–relevant regions (MPFC, TPJ, TP). The task explicitly required situational understanding and future prediction, constructs relevant to perception/understanding of others. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social/emotional face processing and reports whole-brain, univariate control-group activation maps, the sample comprises adolescents aged 12–18 (group means ~15 years). There is no separate healthy adult (age 17–65) subgroup reported or analyzed separately. Thus the study fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one group of healthy adult participants (17–65). All other inclusion criteria are met, but failure to meet the age requirement mandates exclusion.

This is an original fMRI study using a social-emotional task (viewing traffic-awareness videos designed to induce empathy—perception/understanding of others). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=20, males aged 20–28), satisfying the age and healthy-sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (CV > NV) with p<0.05 FWE-corrected clusters in bilateral STS/STG and provides coordinates and figures; these are clearly described as coming from the healthy/control group. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and reports generalizable healthy-group task activation maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study using the Ultimatum Game, a social exchange task assessing responses to fairness (social interaction/perception of others). Sample includes healthy adult participants (n≈50, ages within adult range) with group-level analyses reported for the healthy MT and CT groups separately. The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked results (e.g., anterior insula, septal region, posterior insula, DLPFC) with voxel coordinates and FDR correction and supplementary tables/figures, not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only findings. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level maps). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (face identity and emotional expression perception), conducted in healthy adults (N=35, mean age 29). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects univariate analyses (whole-brain ANCOVA/ANOVA and specific voxelwise contrasts with FDR<.05), provides Talairach coordinates and figures, and links activation to behavior. It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results, and the healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study using task-based animations to probe agency/intentionality (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Participants: healthy adults (n=12, mean age 25.2) within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise contrasts (High>Low and Low>High) analyzed with SPM2 and whole-brain thresholds (p<0.001 uncorrected), and lists activated regions (STS, IFG, occipital areas, etc.), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. It is not ROI-only, nor resting-state or connectivity-only, and not a non-empirical paper. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study used task-based fMRI during observation of social touch (a social-related task). It includes a separate healthy adult control group (n=21) and reports group-level univariate whole-brain task effects for the social vs. non-social contrast (mean group effects shown, with Supplementary Figure S2 and Table S2 providing peak MNI coordinates), not restricted to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Participants are adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social fMRI task, healthy adult group reported separately, and whole-brain univariate results). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI task study of perception/understanding of self and others (body-perception task), directly addressing social-related processing. Sample: 30 healthy adults (15M/15F), mean age 26, within the 17–65 range; healthy-group results are reported separately (one participant excluded from own-body analyses). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (e.g., own body > scrambled, same-sex/opp-sex > scrambled, parametric “me/not me” contrasts) analyzed with FSL FEAT/FLAME and cluster-corrected thresholds; results are presented in text, figures, and supporting tables of coordinates. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes whole-brain healthy-group task effects). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (prosody perception/production) in healthy adults (n=19, ages 18–58). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., “happy-neutral”, “question-neutral”) analyzed with random-effects models and FDR-corrected whole-brain thresholds and cluster criteria, with results described in text/tables and figures. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and includes whole-brain maps and coordinate results generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants (n=18, ages 18–24) that acquired task-evoked whole-brain BOLD data. The task involved listening to artistic and popular music with beauty ratings, and the authors report group-level, voxelwise whole-brain contrasts (Popular>Notes, Artistic>Notes, Artistic>Popular) with voxel and cluster-level thresholds and coordinate tables. Crucially, the paper interprets greater activation for artistic music in default-mode/ToM and rACC/aPFC regions as engagement of cognitive empathy and social-cognitive (perception/understanding-of-others) processes. The study therefore examines social-related processing (empathic/ToM engagement), includes healthy adults, and provides univariate whole-brain results rather than ROI- or connectivity-only analyses. Although the task is not an explicit social interaction, the reported and interpreted activation in social-cognition/ToM networks satisfies the review’s inclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI during a social-related Face Matching Task (implicit perception of others' emotional expressions—fear vs neutral), meeting the review’s domain of social processing (perception/understanding of others). Sample: 10 healthy adults (mean age 25), within the 17–65 range and reported separately. The paper includes group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses: first-level GLM contrasts and second-level one-sample t-tests (face processing, fear>neutral, etc.) with results presented (Tables/Figures in Supplementary Material), satisfying the whole-brain evidence criterion. Although the study also performs ICA, it does not rely solely on connectivity/ICA; univariate whole-brain maps for the healthy group are provided. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, participants in range). Therefore it should be included.

This is a task-based fMRI study of facial emotion discrimination (social perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (control group: 27 participants aged 19–35). The paper reports whole-brain, univariate task-evoked results including within-group contrasts for the normal control (NC) group (regional activations and cluster tables with FWE-corrected p-values and voxel counts), not only ROI or connectivity analyses. Healthy participants are reported separately from the excessive smartphone group, and results for the NC are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, ages within range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (honesty/trust) in healthy adults (N=31, mean age 24.3). The task is explicitly social (take-advice game and subsequent trust game). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (voxel-level p<0.001, cluster-level FWE-corrected p<0.05) with coordinates, figures, and supplementary tables. Results are presented for the healthy participant group and are generalizable to the healthy adult population within the 17–65 age range. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (ages within range) using theory-of-mind tasks, the reported analyses are ROI-based MVPA and ROI selection (individual ToM localizers). The manuscript does not report any group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps or whole-brain contrasts for the healthy/control group (no tables of coordinates or described group voxelwise activation maps are provided in the full text). Because the review requires at least one group-level whole-brain task activation map, this study does not meet the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This fMRI study investigates emotional prosody processing, a social-communication / perception-of-others task, using both behavioral and task-based fMRI paradigms. The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n≈21–22; ages 20–46) reported separately alongside an ASD group. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (e.g., emotional vs. neutral prosody; complex vs. basic; implicit vs. explicit) with FWE cluster correction, conjunction maps, and results explicitly described for the control group (not ROI-only). Analyses are generalizable to healthy adults and meet the age-range criterion. Although the study also includes a clinical ASD group, control-group whole-brain activation maps and coordinate results are presented, satisfying inclusion and not violating exclusion criteria. Therefore the study qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study that uses task-based paradigms probing social cognition (approachability and intelligence judgements from faces). It includes a healthy adult sample (n=47; ages mean ~32, range within 17–65) reported separately from the ASD group. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts for healthy participants (social vs gender judgments) with statistical maps, cluster-corrected results and peak coordinates presented for within-group and between-group analyses. Whole-brain thresholds and SPM results are described (P<0.001 within-group; P<0.005 between-group; cluster-level correction). It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=21, ages within 17–65) and reports group-level univariate whole-brain analyses (a whole-brain analysis reported at p<0.001 uncorrected with peak coordinates and SPM maps). The task involves observation of others’ hand actions and investigation of mirror-system responses, which falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ — a social-related construct. Thus it meets sample, task relevance, and whole-brain evidence criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=21, mean age 24.6) that investigates social cognition (perception and understanding of others via bodies and trait inferences). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Bodies>Names, Traits>Neutral, and the interaction [(BodiesTraits>BodiesNeutral)>(NamesTraits>NamesNeutral)]) with cluster-level statistics, figures, and supplementary tables/coordinates. Although the paper also includes PPI connectivity analyses, it additionally provides univariate voxelwise results for the healthy adult sample, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain evidence. Participants fall within the 17–65 age range, and results for the healthy group are reported directly. The study is empirical original research using task-based fMRI and is not ROI-only, resting-state-only, or solely between-group contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: empirical fMRI study of social/self-referential processing (VV-SORP-T) in healthy adults; sample of 20 healthy women aged 18–52 (within 17–65); reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts and maps (voxel-wise p<0.005 with cluster thresholds, tables/figures of activations and coordinates), not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Results are reported for the healthy group and generalizable as within-group whole-brain activation maps. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (conceptual and agentic self-referential recollection) in healthy adults (N=18, ages 19–29). The paper reports group-level voxelwise task-evoked analyses, including whole-brain results and family-wise error corrected clusters (as well as coordinate tables and conjunction analyses), not limited to ROI-only findings. The healthy adult sample is within the 17–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI, only connectivity, non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (perception of fearful faces and gaze direction). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=22, mean age 23.7, within 17–65) with results reported separately. The paper presents group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses for the control group (within-group contrast AVERTED>DIRECT) using appropriate FSL mixed-effects and permutation testing with FWE correction (p<0.05) and reports/visualizes significant cortical activations. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (task fMRI, healthy adult group, whole-brain univariate results) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing (attentional orienting to eye gaze vs arrows — social perception/communication). Participants: 22 healthy adults (mean age 22.95), within the 17–65 range, with results reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate analyses (main effects and interactions; voxel-wise thresholding with FWE correction and MNI coordinates/tables) and supplementary ROI/SVC analyses — not ROI-only or connectivity-only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion requirements for whole‑brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study that includes a social-related task (an altruism/dictator-game task probing others’ payoffs, ethics, and partner-focused processing). The sample includes healthy adult participants (N=55 for altruism task; subset N=37 completed the food task), ages within 17–65. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level analyses: GLMs (trial-wise choice regressors) were estimated and used for both univariate and multivariate searchlight analyses, with group-level statistical maps and cluster-level FWE-corrected results and MNI coordinates reported (including univariate comparisons and ROI-conjunctions). Results are presented as whole-brain effects generalizable to the healthy group rather than limited subgroups. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=23; mean age 26.4) using a social perception task manipulating animacy/‘like-me’ cues. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., human>robot, belief manipulations, interactions) with voxelwise thresholds and tables/figures of activations and MNI coordinates. Results are not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or patient groups. Whole-brain findings are described in text, figures, and coordinate tables, and are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria (fMRI during social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain univariate group results) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study investigates social gaze perception and its influence on action control (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others). Sample comprises healthy adults (n=30, ages 19–41). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked activation analyses (congruency and gaze main effects and interactions) with cluster thresholds and coordinates and figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although psychophysiological interaction analyses are also reported, whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only results, connectivity-only, non-healthy only, age out of range, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This fMRI study includes a healthy adult control group (n=8 males, mean age ~23) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked results for the control group (one-sample t-tests showing activation and deactivation maps, conjunctions, and two-sample contrasts; coordinates and maps are described). The task involves processing prosodic connected speech, which falls under social communication/perception of others, matching the review’s social-related constructs. Although the study also includes an HFA group, control results are reported separately. Sample size is small and controls are male-only, but neither violates the inclusion/exclusion criteria (whole-brain healthy-group task effects are present and clearly reported). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study of social processing (empathy for pain). It includes a healthy adult control group (ages in reported range 22–63) with group-level, univariate whole-brain task analyses reported (whole-brain results and coordinates described; Supplementary Table 1; contrasts such as High Pain–Low Pain in the Other are reported, and control vs ASD whole-brain contrasts are presented). Although ROI analyses are used, the paper additionally reports whole-brain, group-level activation maps/coordinates for relevant contrasts, clearly linked to the healthy/control participants. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusions.

While this fMRI study examines social-cognitive processes (action understanding, theory of mind) and includes a healthy adult control group, the paper primarily reports between-group contrasts (ALS > HC, HC > ALS) and conjunction/ROI/SVC analyses. It does not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level (within-group) task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group (i.e., a main effect or within-group contrast map for HCs). Therefore it fails the inclusion requirement for reporting at least one whole-brain, univariate task-evoked healthy-group map and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study (dyadic/dfMRI) of social interaction (eye contact) in healthy adults (19 pairs; ages 18–33). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (GLM, paired t-tests) and presents thresholded activation maps, cluster information, atlas-based labels, and coordinates for exogenous/endogenous contrasts—i.e., task-evoked, voxelwise results generalizable to healthy adults. Tasks are social (reciprocal eye contact) and methods/analyses meet whole-brain reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This fMRI study includes a healthy adult control group (n=33, ages 18–65) analyzed separately from the schizophrenia patients, and uses a social-related task (self- and other-reflection) relevant to perception/understanding of self and others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts for the control group (e.g., Self>Facts, Other>Facts, Other>Self) with figures and supplementary tables of results, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is empirical fMRI task data (not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or resting-state), and healthy-group effects are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (women aged 18–35) performing a self-related social evaluation (‘would you like to smell like this?’), which maps onto the review construct Perception and Understanding of Self. Group-level, univariate task contrasts are reported (e.g., ‘self’-peptide minus solvent and ‘self’-peptide minus ‘non-self’-peptide) with activation coordinates in MNI space and statistical thresholds; the authors state that whole-brain analysis was performed and provide peak coordinates (right middle frontal cortex) for the healthy participant group. Thus the paper includes a healthy adult sample, a social-related fMRI task, and group-level voxelwise task-evoked results that are generalizable to the healthy adult population. Although ROI analyses are emphasized, whole-brain contrasts and coordinates are reported, satisfying the inclusion criteria.

This fMRI study examines social perception of others (responses to facial disfigurement) using a gender-judgement task with faces before/after surgical treatment — a clearly social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Sample comprises healthy adults (n=31 in fMRI analysis; ages 18–35), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise contrasts (SnPM nonparametric group analysis, cluster-level FWE correction) with reported increased and decreased activations (fusiform, occipito-temporal, medial ACC, etc.), fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results are not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and are reported for the healthy group. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of multisensory non-verbal social cues (animated human face and vocalizations) engaging social perception/understanding processes. It includes a healthy adult sample (fMRI group: 10 healthy right-handed males, ages 24–37). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts and statistical maps (conditions vs rest; AV versus AUD+VIS; voxelwise t tests with multiple-comparison correction and activation maps/tables), not ROI-only analyses. No exclusion criteria apply, so it meets all inclusion requirements for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (behavioral N=27; fMRI N=29, ages within 17–65) investigating social-related processing (learning about others’ preferences, simulation and valuation for self vs. others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses (repetition suppression and contrasts reported with cluster-level FWE correction and peak coordinates in mPFC, pMFC, STS, striatum, visual cortex) rather than ROI-only or solely connectivity analyses. Healthy-group task effects are clearly presented and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study tests social tasks (theory-of-mind and attribution-of-attention) in healthy adult samples (ages within 17–65), the main activation analyses are based on localized ICA within a temporoparietal ROI and subsequent seed-to-voxel functional connectivity. The paper does not report a group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked activation map (e.g., GLM contrast of belief>photo) generalizable to the healthy group; reported IC maps are confined to the TPJ mask and the whole-brain results are connectivity maps. Per the review’s inclusion criteria, at least one whole-brain task activation map for the healthy group is required. Because that criterion is not met, the study should be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult women (ages 21–48) using task-evoked presentation of erotic pictures and videos depicting other people, which fits within social-related processing (perception/understanding of others, affiliation/sexual interest). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task contrasts (within-group one-sample contrasts and male vs. female stimulus contrasts) with corrected thresholds (p<0.05 FWE) and cluster reports, clearly reported for the healthy groups. Although an ROI analysis was also performed, whole-brain univariate results for healthy adult groups are presented and generalizable to the healthy sample. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI, only connectivity, non-healthy-only sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI task study in healthy adults (final N=24, ages 19–31). The task is explicitly social (cooperation vs. competition; self- and other-related ability estimation), matching constructs such as perception/understanding of self and others. The paper reports univariate, group-level task-evoked whole-brain analyses identifying regions (pgACC, area 9) and relating activation to behavioral measures; effects are described at the group level with statistical tests (e.g., t and correlation values). Results are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group contrasts, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (kinship and moral dilemma) in healthy adults. Sample: 30 healthy female adults (19–39), within the 17–65 range. The study reports voxelwise whole-brain analyses: inter-subject correlation (ISC) maps during movie viewing and group-level GLM results for a moral-dilemma decision task, with cluster/coordinate tables and multiple-comparison correction. Results are reported for the healthy group (N=30) and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and does not involve clinical groups. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although this fMRI study examines personal familiarity (socially relevant: familiar faces/places tied to affiliation/attachment) and reports whole-brain, group-level task activations for the healthy control group, the control participants are described as 'healthy elderly' and the sample is not characterized as adults in the 17–65 age range required by the review. No subgroup of healthy adults within 17–65 is reported separately. Therefore the study fails the sample age inclusion criterion and must be excluded despite meeting the other criteria (social task and whole-brain healthy-group results).

This is an fMRI study of emotional prosody decoding that explicitly examines perception/understanding of others’ emotions (complex vs. simple social emotions), a social-cognitive task relevant to the review’s constructs (social communication; perception/understanding of others). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=19 males, ages 18–51), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (emotional vs. neutral; complex vs. simple; analyses corrected for multiple comparisons and a pitch-controlled contrast), clearly attributed to the healthy participant group. It is not ROI-only, nor resting-state or connectivity-only, and provides whole-brain statistical maps/tables described in the text. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (anticipation of touching an animate vs inanimate target). The sample consists of healthy adult participants (32 males, ages 21–33) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps (paired-sample t-tests and covariate analyses) with corrected thresholds (FDR) and coordinates, clearly identified as from the healthy participant group. Although resting-state and ROI analyses are also included, whole-brain univariate task results are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception/understanding of others; mirror and mentalizing systems) in healthy adults (N=16, mean age 22.8). The paper reports group-level task-evoked contrasts (main effects and interactions) and provides stereotaxic coordinates and statistical details of BOLD peaks. Although analyses used masks for MNS and MS, second-level contrasts were conducted and reported with coordinate tables, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain, group-level univariate task results for a healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only; not connectivity-only; participants within 17–65). Therefore the study meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adult participants (N=36, ages within 17–65) and uses a task probing social cognition, the reported neuroimaging results are confined to a priori vACC small-volume ROI analyses (SVC) with no clear reporting of unmasked, whole-brain group-level, voxelwise task activation maps. The Methods and Results describe ROI-based small-volume correction and do not present whole-brain task contrasts or coordinates generalizable to the healthy adult population. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one whole-brain univariate group-level task activation map.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (empathy for pain/prosocial behavior) in healthy adults (male participants aged 18–40). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task analyses (e.g., INJECTION > QTIP and BIOPSY > QTIP) with family-wise error correction over the whole brain and provides peak coordinates and conjunction results; contrasts are derived from healthy participant groups (stress and control), and results are generalizable to healthy adults. All other inclusion criteria met (task-based fMRI, healthy adult sample, whole-brain univariate maps reported). Note: most reported whole-brain results focus on group comparisons (stress vs control), but these are group-level, univariate, voxelwise maps from healthy participant groups, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social evaluation (perception/understanding of others) with a healthy adult sample (N=20, ages 18–29). The authors report group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (multilevel voxelwise models, cluster-thresholded maps, peak MNI coordinates) relating trial type and judgment valence to BOLD activation (including DLPFC and dACC). Results are not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or clinical groups, and whole-brain task activation maps/coordinates are clearly described. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study reports task-based fMRI in a healthy sample (N=56 after exclusions) with participants aged 17–20 (within the 17–65 inclusion range). It uses a social feedback task probing social evaluation (a social-related construct). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (negative>neutral, positive>neutral, conjunction) with whole-brain FWE-corrected results and peak coordinates, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. It is not ROI-only nor limited to connectivity analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study that directly examines neural responses to social versus non-social stimuli in a sample of healthy adults (N=14 analyzed; ages 23–50). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (social > non-social contrast) with voxelwise thresholding and FDR correction, and presents results in figures/tables and conjunctions with NeuroSynth maps. The task is social-related (perception/processing of social scenes) and the healthy-control group results are reported separately and clearly. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or inappropriate age range) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of task-based whole-brain fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI task study of face perception/social cognition (perception/understanding of others). The sample includes a healthy adult group (n=51 adults, ages 18–42) reported separately. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Face > Object/Texture) using mixed-effects (FLAME) and thresholded statistical maps, with results shown in tables/figures and used to define ROIs. The study is empirical, not solely ROI- or connectivity-based, and reports healthy-group whole-brain activation maps generalizable to adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

While this is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (passive viewing of dynamic facial expressions; n=18, ages within 17–65), the reported group-level results are presented using region-of-interest analyses with small-volume correction (WFU Pick Atlas masks) rather than as unmasked, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps. The Methods and Results repeatedly describe ROI/SVC-based contrasts and conjunctions and report coordinates from these ROIs; there is no clear presentation of an uncorrected or whole-brain corrected, unmasked group activation map generalized to the healthy adult population. Because the review’s inclusion criterion requires at least one group-level whole-brain voxelwise task activation map, this paper does not meet that requirement and should be excluded.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants using a social-cognitive (face processing/theory-of-mind) paradigm. Group-level univariate whole-brain analyses are reported (one-sample t-tests and ANOVA; whole-brain results with FWE correction and coordinates/tables/figures described), and results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group (N=74). The paper is not ROI-only and includes whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (observation of dyadic aggressive interactions) in healthy adults (15 male participants; analyzed N=14; mean age 23.6 within 17–65). The paper reports group-level whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (GLM contrasts vs baseline and focus-on-aggressor vs focus-on-victim), with cluster-size correction and Talairach-space reporting; results described in text and supplemented by figures/tables. It is not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses (although connectivity analyses are also reported). Healthy-group whole-brain task effects are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of empathy/mentalising (social-related processing) in healthy adults (final fMRI sample N=34, ages 20–30). The task (modified Empathic Accuracy Task) is a social-cognitive paradigm probing perception and understanding of others’ emotions. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (emotional>neutral; parametric modulation by Z-EA; time-varying correlations with intensity ratings) with TFCE FWE-corrected results and peak coordinates/tables. Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI of social cognition (theory-of-mind stories contrasting cooperation, deception, and combined scenarios). Sample comprises healthy adults (n=13, ages 22–38) within the 17–65 range with results reported separately. The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (exploratory ToM vs non-ToM contrast with cluster thresholds) and provides peak coordinates and mapped activations; these whole-brain results were then used to define ROIs for further contrasts. It is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. Therefore the study provides usable whole-brain task-evoked activation data in healthy adults and should be INCLUDED.

This is an empirical fMRI study of a social-related task (imitation/observation of emotional faces) in healthy adults (initial N=28; final analyzed N=20; ages 18–55). The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses: a GLM in SPM8 (replicated task PLS results) and whole-brain voxelwise PLS maps (bootstrap-thresholded voxel patterns and figures/supplementary GLM figure), not limited to ROI or resting-state/seed-connectivity only. Results are presented as group-level, univariate task-evoked spatial maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social perception in healthy adults: participants (N=14, mean age 22) viewed eyes with dynamically manipulated pupil size (social cue). The paper reports second-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate analyses (group-level SPM results), including a whole-brain corrected main effect of viewing eye stimuli and cluster/coordinate-based whole-brain results for pupil-change effects, plus ROI results. Thus it meets: 1) task-based fMRI on social-related processing (perception/understanding of others), 2) healthy adult sample within 17–65, and 3) group-level whole-brain task activation maps/coordinates generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not patient-only). Therefore include.

While the paper includes a healthy adult control group (n=18) and uses task-based fMRI of emotion-word processing (a social-related construct), it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The manuscript provides a whole-brain map pooled across all participants and reports between-group (control > ASC) contrasts at whole-brain level and ROI-based within-group analyses, but no standalone, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. According to the review inclusion criteria, studies that provide only between-group contrasts or ROI results without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task map must be excluded.

This fMRI study includes a healthy adult control group (NT; n=18, mean age ~25.8, within 17–65) and reports task-based social/face-processing contrasts. The task probes social perception/emotional processing (Thatcher Illusion with cued attention to eyes/mouth), which falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts and statistical maps for the healthy control group (within-group whole-brain activation for NT, thresholded and described in text and figures), allowing generalizable healthy-group task effects. Although a clinical ASD group is also included, healthy-group results are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state-only, age outside range, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

While this paper uses task fMRI during a social (gaze) paradigm and includes a healthy adult control group, it does not clearly report an unmasked, whole-brain voxelwise task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. The main inferential results for the theory-of-mind regions were evaluated using a priori ROI small-volume corrections, and the whole-brain FWE-corrected contrasts described (e.g., faces > null) appear to have been used to define networks across groups rather than reporting a control-group whole-brain map. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task effect clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group, this criterion is not clearly met; therefore the study should be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (recognition of communicative intentions from prosody). Participants: 22 healthy adult native German speakers (mean age 27.35), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate group-level contrasts (CLEAR > AMBIGUOUS and AMBIGUOUS > CLEAR) with voxelwise thresholding and cluster-level FWE correction, and provides activation maps and coordinates. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, the study also presents primary task-evoked whole-brain activation maps for the healthy group (not ROI-only, not resting-state, and not solely between-group contrasts). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study using the Cyberball social exclusion paradigm (social-related processing). It includes a healthy adult control group (HC; n=28) reported separately.
