The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate results for the healthy controls (main effect of condition in HC: left anterior insula, voxel p-FWE <0.05, k≥10), which meets the requirement for a whole-brain task-evoked statistical map generalizable to healthy adults. Participants are adult females (within the 17–65 range). The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied.

While this is an fMRI study of social impression formation in healthy adult participants (N=60, ages within 17–65) using task-evoked data, the paper does not report a group-level univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map or contrast for the healthy sample. The manuscript focuses on multivariate behavioral PLS results and reports PLS-derived voxel saliences and bootstrapped clusters; it references a prior univariate analysis of the same dataset but does not present univariate whole-brain statistical maps or coordinate tables as group-level task-evoked effects in this paper. Because the meta-analysis requires at least one univariate whole-brain task activation map from the healthy/control group, this study does not meet that criterion and should be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=27, ages 24–26) that used task-evoked functional MRI while participants viewed social interaction scenes (cooperative vs affective). The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (FWE-corrected and exploratory uncorrected maps), direct condition contrasts, conjunctions, and tables/figures of whole-brain activation loci. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain results for the healthy adult group are clearly presented and generalizable. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and there are no exclusions (not solely ROI, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

While the study uses an fMRI social task (face processing) and includes healthy adult participants, the primary whole‑brain, voxelwise analyses were conducted on a mixed sample of patients and controls and the paper does not report a group-level whole-brain task activation map explicitly for the healthy/control group. The independent replication sample consists of healthy adults but used an anatomical ROI approach (fusiform gyrus), not an unmasked whole‑brain voxelwise map. Thus the manuscript fails the requirement to provide at least one group-level, univariate whole‑brain task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (study 1: final n=41, study 2: final n=39; ages 18–24). Tasks explicitly probe self-related processing and social cognition/mentalizing during article exposure. In addition to ROI analyses, the paper presents group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked analyses (whole-brain maps and cluster/FDR-corrected results and tables) derived from the healthy samples. Results are reported for the healthy/control groups and are generalizable to healthy adults rather than limited to a clinical subgroup. Thus the study satisfies the fMRI social-task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task is social (decisions influenced by another person; taps perception/understanding of others and social cognition). Sample consists of healthy adult participants (n=51, mean age 22) within 17–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., controlled > free decisions) with cluster-level FWE correction and peak MNI coordinates and statistical maps; results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. The study also includes additional connectivity analyses, but these are supplemental to whole-brain task activations (not the sole report). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (trustworthiness and fear appraisal of faces) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=17; ages 18–45). The study used whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (mixed-effects group analyses via FSL/FEAT) and reports whole-brain task contrasts and cluster results (including coordinates referenced in Supplementary Tables) for task-evoked activity and task contrasts (fearfulness vs. trustworthiness and trustworthiness-specific networks), as well as group comparisons. The healthy control group is explicitly reported and results are described for task-related activation (including control ROI responses and whole-brain contrasts), meeting the requirement for whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or out-of-range ages) are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study that includes a healthy adult group (N=19, ages 22–31) within the 17–65 range. The task is social-related (direct, reflected, and close-other self-evaluations across social, academic, and physical domains). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (2×4×3 whole-brain repeated-measures ANOVA; voxel-wise threshold p<0.005, cluster-extent k=64, AlphaSim FWE correction) and describes significant main effects and interactions; separate adult and adolescent comparisons are reported (with adult results described in main text and supplementary materials). Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked maps from a healthy adult sample performing a social task.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (eye-gaze perception) in a sample of healthy adults (N=18; ages 18–30). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain second-level analyses: specifically, SPM-t maps showing voxels whose activation (variable vs. constant gaze contrast) correlate with Autism Spectrum Quotient (AQ) across participants, thresholded at p<0.05 whole-brain FDR and reported with coordinates. These are univariate, within-group whole-brain task-evoked results (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only) and are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Although the simple main effect contrast lacked significant activations, the AQ regression constitutes an acceptable within-group whole-brain map generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of nulliparous healthy adult women (ages 19–29) using task-based social stimuli (infant cries and faces) addressing social/affiliative and emotion perception processes. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise contrasts (e.g., high- vs low-distress cries, happy vs neutral faces) with correction for multiple comparisons and displays results in figures/tables. Participants are healthy adults within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI of gesture planning/execution (a social-communication/social-action task) in healthy adult controls (n=25) alongside patients. The paper provides within-group, whole-brain, univariate task activation results for the healthy/control group (within-group results and whole-brain contrasts are described and thresholded), not only between-group contrasts or ROI/connectivity analyses. Healthy participants are adults and results for the healthy group are reported separately and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain univariate healthy-group maps). No exclusion criteria are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task: fMRI during a social-related approach-avoidance task using social vs nonsocial emotional scenes (social processing). (2) Sample: healthy adult participants (male students, n=76 analyzed; mean age 21.35, within 17–65). (3) Whole-brain evidence: although many primary ROI/SVC results are reported, the paper explicitly states exploratory whole-brain analyses were conducted and reported (P<.05 corrected) and presents group-level task-evoked contrasts derived from the healthy sample (maps/tables reported in main text and/or supplementary materials). Results are univariate, group-level, and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical fMRI work (task-based) and does not fall under exclusion categories (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Hence it should be included.

This paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (combined n=59 across three studies, ages consistent with adult range), using social-related paradigms (person knowledge: famous faces/names; socially relevant concept words). The manuscript presents group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., social > non-social semantics) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster correction, peak coordinates, figures, and detailed whole-brain results described in the text. Healthy/control group results are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and not ROI-only (ROIs are supplementary to whole-brain analyses). No exclusion criteria are met, so the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses task fMRI of social/emotional face processing and includes a healthy control group within the target age range, the full text does not report a clear group-level univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group. Reported univariate activations appear to be ‘across all participants’ (averaged) and the main reported neuroimaging results focus on PPI (seed-based connectivity) and between-group comparisons. The paper therefore provides connectivity and between-group contrasts but lacks an unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group, violating the review’s whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

Although the study uses a face-processing fMRI task in healthy young adults (social perception), it does not report group-level univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy/control group. The imaging analyses are ROI-based interregional BOLD correlations and structural covariance across 25 predefined ROIs, with group comparisons performed on average correlation matrices. No whole-brain voxelwise activation maps or coordinate tables of healthy-group task activations are presented; therefore the study fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.
